chameleon.core.namespace
Class Namespace

java.lang.Object
  chameleon.core.element.ElementImpl<Namespace,Namespace>
      chameleon.core.namespace.Namespace
All Implemented Interfaces:
Declaration<Namespace,Namespace,SimpleNameSignature,Namespace>, DeclarationContainer<Namespace,Namespace>, TargetDeclaration<Namespace,Namespace,SimpleNameSignature,Namespace>, Element<Namespace,Namespace>, Target<Namespace,Namespace>, NamespaceOrType<Namespace,Namespace,SimpleNameSignature,Namespace>
Direct Known Subclasses:
NamespaceAlias, RegularNamespace
public abstract class Namespace
extends ElementImpl<Namespace,Namespace>
implements NamespaceOrType<Namespace,Namespace,SimpleNameSignature,Namespace>, DeclarationContainer<Namespace,Namespace>, TargetDeclaration<Namespace,Namespace,SimpleNameSignature,Namespace>

Namespaces are a completely logical structure. You do not explicitly create a namespace, but query it using the getOrCreateNamespace method.

The declarations in a namespace are not stored directly in that namespace. Instead, they are stored in namespace parts. A namespace contains a number of namespace parts. The reason for this decision is that some language, such as C#, allow a programmer to add elements to different namespaces in a single compilation unit (file). Namespace parts can also contain other namespace parts.

For example, if you write a namespace declaration in C#, that will correspond to a namespace part in the model. Thus, "namespace a {class{X} namespace b.c{class Y{} }} namespace d {class Z{}} adds class X to namespace a, lass Y to namespace a.b.c, and class Z to namespace d.

We chose to unify this structure for all languages. For example, a Java compilation unit with a package declaration will contain a namespace part for the root namespace. A Java compilation with a package declaration contains a namespace part for that namespace (package).

getOrCreateNamespace

public abstract Namespace getOrCreateNamespace(String name)
                                        throws LookupException

Return the namespace with the fullyqualified name that equals the fqn of this namespace concatenated with the given name.

If the namespace does not exist yet, it will be created.

Parameters:
name - The qualified name relative to this namespace
Throws:
LookupException

targetContext

public LookupStrategy targetContext()
Description copied from interface: TargetDeclaration
Return the target context of this target. A target context is the context used to look up elements that are expressed relative to a target. For example, when looking up a.b, first a is looked up in the current context. After that, b must be looked up in the context of the element returned by the lookup of a. But b must not be lookup up as if it were used in the lexical context of the class representing the type of a. Therefore, two contexts are provided: a lexical context and a target context. For example: 1) in "expr.f", "f" must be looked up in the static type of "expr", and not in its lexical context, which is the current lexical context. 2) in "typename.f", "f" must be looked up in the type represented by "typename" 3) in "packagename.f", "f" must be looked up in the package represented by "package"

Specified by:
targetContext in interface TargetDeclaration<Namespace,Namespace,SimpleNameSignature,Namespace>
Specified by:
targetContext in interface Target<Namespace,Namespace>

alias

selectionDeclaration

public Namespace selectionDeclaration()
Description copied from interface: Declaration
Because some declarations, such as formal generic parameters, are stubs for other declarations, the lookup process invokes resolveForMatch on a declaration before giving it to the selection method of a DeclarationSelector. A formal generic parameter, for example, will return a stub type with the same name as itself, but which behaves like the upperbound of its type constraints. By creating a type with the same name as itself, the DeclarationSelector for types does not have to know about the existance of formal generic parameters. In most cases this method simply returns the current object. Resolve this declaration. In case of a direct declaration, the method returns the current object. In case of an indirection, the indirection will be resolved, and the resulting element will be returned.

Specified by:
selectionDeclaration in interface Declaration<Namespace,Namespace,SimpleNameSignature,Namespace>

actualDeclaration

public Namespace actualDeclaration()
Description copied from interface: Declaration
As explained in the resolveForMatch method, formal generic parameters create stub types for matching. In case of an instantiated generic parameter, though, the end result of a lookup should be the actual type argument, and not a stub. Therefore, the resolveForResult method performs a final transformation. In case of a stub of an instantiated generic parameter, the actual type that is used as an argument is returned.

Specified by:
actualDeclaration in interface Declaration<Namespace,Namespace,SimpleNameSignature,Namespace>
